column1: Gonesse is a commune in the north-eastern suburbs of Paris
column2: France. It is located 16.5 km (10.3 mi) from the centre of Paris.

column1: The commune lies immediately north of Le Bourget Airport
column2: and it is six kilometres (four miles) south-west of Charles de Gaulle International Airport.
cereals have been grown in Gonesse. In the period of the 12th through to the 16th centuries
column3: the cultivation of grain was supplemented by drapery
column4: in particular the production of the coarse woollen material of the gaunace. The commune was an important producer of wheat for the Parisian market in modern times
column5: until the decline of its bakery trade at the end of the 18th century helped feed a strong migration to the capital.

column1: The world's first hydrogen filled balloon—the unmanned balloon launched by Jacques Charles and the Robert brothers from the Champ de Mars in Paris on 27 August 1783—flew for 45 minutes and landed in Gonesse
column2: where the reportedly terrified local peasants destroyed it with pitchforks. This caused the government to issue a statement on the harmlessness and the scientific value of such experiments.
Marshal Grouchy arrived in Gonesse in the course of the War of the Sixth Coalition
column4: 000 troops and 120 artillery pieces. On 2 July
column5: the Duke of Wellington made his headquarters at the commune.

column2: the property Frapart (the Castle) is used as the main establishment of the urban administration.Jean Camus
column5: and Albert Drouhot from Gonesse belonged to the French Resistance movement during the German occupation of France from 1940 to 1944.

column2: Air France Flight 4590—a Concorde supersonic transport—crashed onto a hotel in the town after a tyre blew out
column3: caused by running over a strip of metal that had fallen off a DC-10 at nearby Charles de Gaulle International Airport. The crash led to the deaths of all 109 people on board and four more on the ground. The Concorde crash occurred fewer than 6 km from Goussainville
column4: the site of the crash of the supersonic Tupolev Tu-144 during the 1973 Paris Air Show.

column1: Gonesse has been twinned with the town of Leonessa in Rieti
Among the places worthwhile to visit in the town are the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul
column5: and the estates of Malmaison and of Coulanges.

column1: Gonesse is served neither by the Paris Métro
column3: nor the suburban rail network. The closest station is the Villiers-le-Bel – Gonesse – Arnouville station on the Paris RER line D. This station is located in the neighbouring commune of Arnouville-lès-Gonesse
column4: 2.6 km (1.6 mi) from Gonesse town centre.

column2: the commune had 20 municipal primary schools with a total of 3
column4: including 11 pre-schools (écoles maternelles) with a total of 1
column5: 389 pupils (in addition to 20 children in toute petite programmes) and nine elementary schools with 2

King Philip Augustus was born in Gonesse on 21 August 1165.
